content.text: A **sound** argument is one that is both valid AND has true premises. Soundness guarantees that the conclusion is actually true - it's the gold standard for arguments.

content.definition: An argument that is (1) valid (the conclusion follows from the premises) AND (2) has all true premises. A sound argument guarantees a true conclusion.

content.title: A Sound Argument
premises: All humans are mortal. (TRUE - empirically verified)
Socrates was a human. (TRUE - historically verified)
content.note: This argument is sound because: (1) The form is valid (All A are B, X is A, therefore X is B), and (2) both premises are actually true.

content.title: Valid but Unsound
premises: All birds can fly. (FALSE - penguins, ostriches, kiwis can't)
content.note: The form is valid, but the first premise is false, making the argument unsound. We can't trust the conclusion.

content.text: Logic focuses primarily on **validity** because we can analyze argument structure without knowing whether premises are actually true. Determining truth often requires empirical investigation - science, history, observation.

content.question: An argument has a valid form but one false premise. What do we call this argument?
content.explanation: A valid argument with at least one false premise is called 'valid but unsound.' The conclusion may or may not be true - we just can't trust the argument to guarantee it.
